div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, August 15, 1940
div1.opener:
Copy to Mrs Phillips to Show Moran
Sent Copy of Memorandum
& Photos 1-2-5-6-11b-13b-14-39-42
45-46-53-62 & her fathers old prints
August 15, 1940
Senora Estella Agramonte Rodriguez-Leon
311 Calle 15 entre H e I
Vedado, Havana, Cuba
My dear Senora Rodriguez-Leon
div1.p:
I so appreciated your kind note and hasten to tell you that I
think your apologies were entirely unnecessary. I know how busy you must
be. I, myself have been very busy and only recently have been able to
collect my notes, written often very hastily, sometimes written from memory
at the end of the day. These I have assembled in the enclosed, confidential
memorandum, and hasten to tell you that this memorandum is only being sent
to Dr. Hutchison, the president of W. and J., so that he may get some of the
background of the yellow fever work, and it is also being sent to General
Kean and General Truby, who were so closely associated with the work of your
father and his colleagues. A copy is going to Moran, in order that he may
help me straighten out some of the details. Although it is long, I think you
will find it interesting to read, and I would be most grateful indeed if you
would read it critically, and make any comment on it that you choose to make.
I am so anxious that the truth shall be told, insofar as it can glorify those
concerned, and if I have through error made any mis-statement or misquoted you
or anyone else, I am most anxious to have it corrected. When my final story
is published, naturally it will be more interesting to have your remarks and
those of others given in the first person in quotation marks, and I would be
most grateful if you could amplify your story just as much as possible. I
would never ask you to go to the bother of writing out corrections and ampli-
fications in long hand. This is too much work and I am going to make a suggestion
which I hope you will think appropriate. Mrs. R. Hart Phillips, Manzana de
Gomez 553, Havana, is the widow of the former correspondent of the New York
Times. She does secretarial work and helped me considerably when I was in
Havana. Would you permit me to suggest that, at your convenience, she come
to your house some afternoon or evening and take dictation from you, receiving
whatever suggestions, criticisms and amplifications of this memorandum that
you see fit to make. She will then make a carbon copy, submit it for your
final inspection, and send it to me, and I shall be delighted to pay the cost.
I am hoping to make this arrangement between her and two or three other Havana
correspondents.

Please remember that this memorandum is confidential in the sense
that it will not be published in this form and that any remarks I have made which
would seem detrimental to those of the government or those from the Finlay Institute
whom I met, are merely written here for personal reasons, and will of course never
appear in my formal report, either to the Cuban government or in any paper that I
may write for medical historical journals.
May I ask you certain specific questions?

Paragraph 13: Did your father ever tell you anything about Dean's
mental reactions when he had discovered that he had gotten yellow fever? Or did
he ever tell you anything remotely resembling Kissinger's version of this affair?
Kissinger insisted that Lazear had put the mosquito on Dean while he was asleep.

Par. 14: I am particularly anxious that you check this paragraph for
me. Can you give me any further information as to the understanding between your
father and Lazear? Was Reed involved in this understanding and was it official
or merely a gentlemen's agreement?

Pars. 15 and 16: I would be most appreciative if you would amplify
and comment on these paragraphs.

Par. 17: Again I am anxious to find out if there was any correspondence
between Reed in Washington and your father and Lazear in Havana regarding Carroll's
illness, and later regarding Lazear's death.

Par. 32: Do you know of any tree expert in Havana who would be willing
to visit the tree on the false site of “Camp Lazear” and give me some idea as to age,
or who might be at least willing to look at my photograph of this tree and express
an opinion?

Par. 50: I should appreciate your reaction to this paragraph, and I
can assure that it is not meant as criticism on my part. I think that Americans
know too little about Finlay and Cubans know too little about the work of Reed and
your father.

Par. 52: Do you know whether the National Hospital of the Cuban
army has yet been named for your father or whether any monument has been erected
to Carroll?

Par. 99: I am of course particularly anxious for you to check over
very carefully Par. 99 to 105, and if you can given me any more informal information
on the informal pact between your father and Lazear, this would be most helpful.
I am returning herewith the three photographs which you so kindly loaned me with
a copy of each that we made here. Should anyone else wish copies, rather than
lend your precious photographs again, I should be glad to send you copies from
our films. I am still extremely anxious to find other photographs of the places
and personalities concerned, and while I hesitate to impose upon you, with another
request for you to bother to hunt for your father's photographs, were you to find
them it would be a bonanza to me: Would you be willing to send me your father's
manuscript written in his own hand, the unpublished address given at the time of
the banquet. If you will register this to me, I will have it photostated and return
you not only the original, but a photostat copy by registered, insured post.
So far, I have been unable to obtain a copy of the Hemmeter or the Donnally articles.
You were kind enough to say that if I could not find them, you would lend them to me.
Do not bother to send them yet, as I still have one or two people I want to write
to for them. I asked you where your father was buried. I carelessly forgot to
write this down. I should like to know. Do you have any photographs of his grave?

I cannot tell you how much I appreciate all the wonderful help that you
have given me, and if I can remind American medical men of the glorious work in which
your father participated so nobly, I shall be satisfied to have spent so many hours
in trying to find out new angles of this fascinating story. Mrs. Hench sends you
her kindest regards, both to you and to your family.
